Body: Description: We like to know if there is a session timeout setting for the desktop application running from Stealth Audit server, where we can make configuration change for the application. This is not the timeout session for web console access.

I am wondering if there is timeout session with the server application GUI. In addition, I also like to ask:

 

  1. Is the web console only for viewing report?

ANSWER: Yes the NAA (or NEA) Published Reports console is only for viewing reports.

 

  1. Is there a web GUI/console to configure application settings, like the application GUI on the installed server?

ANSWER: There is a configurable "SessionTimeout" in the "WebServer.exe.Config"

 

"E:Program Files (x86)STEALTHbitsStealthAUDITWebWebServer.exe.Config"

<add key="SessionTimeout" value="15" />

What is the authentication method used for GUI? Is it Kerberos or NTLM or something else? We login with Windows AD account, so I assume it is either Kerberos or NTLM.

 

You are running the application using the current session and token.

There is no additional or secondary authentication.

There is no session timeout analogous to

Mike Candon: Does NAA (and NEA 11.6) use Kerberos authentication?

posted in SWAT Teams: Product Discussions, PM Q&A, Feedback / NAA Core on Monday, April 21, 2025 5:21 PM

+++++

From PM:

+++++

Correct. A few years ago we checked the product since Windows was going to get rid of the option to have NTLM enabled/disable it by default if that would affect the product and we found that wasn't the case that we default to NTLM.

We use Kerberos unless the environment specifies to use NTLM and you enter IP addresses in the product (this isn't always supported depending on part of the product being configured).

+++++

What We've Learned Updated: We never try to use NTLM, only what Windows processes.
There are certain steps that will fail if we cannot authenticate through Kerberos.
However there is nothing that relies on NTLM.

What We've Learned Updated: We never try to use NTLM, only what Windows processes.
There are certain steps that will fail if we cannot authenticate through Kerberos.
However there is nothing that relies on NTLM.

1) A few years ago we checked the product since Windows was going to get rid of the option to have NTLM enabled/disable it by default if that would affect the product and we found that it wasn't the case that we default to NTLM.

2) We do use Kerberos unless the environment specifies to use NTLM and you enter IP addresses in the product (this isn't always supported depending on part of the product being configured).

+++++
From the customer:
+++++
In our environment, NTLM and Kerberos are both enabled, so we need to understand by default is the product use NTLM or it tries Kerberos first and then fail back to NTLM if Kerberos is not supported.
+++++
